title: Designing Reliable AI Tutors for Secondary Education
text:
Epistemisches KI Tutoring


Epistemisches KI Tutoring is angelehnt an „Common Standards for Rigor and Relevance in Teaching Academic Subjects“ von Fred M. Newmann, M. Bruce King und Dana L. Carmichael
Die Autor*innen schlagen vor, dass „authentischer Unterricht“ Aufgaben umfasst, die:

den Aufbau von Wissen (nicht nur bloßes Abrufen) erfordern,
Untersuchung, Analyse, Synthese und/oder Bewertung - höheres Denken - erfordern und,
einen Wert über die Schule hinaus besitzen (bedeutsam für das Leben der Lernenden oder für die Welt).

Was sehr wünschenswert ist, aber im Schulalltag oft zu kurz kommt. Hier kann KI unterstützend wirken.

title: Designing Reliable AI Tutors for Secondary Education
text:
Welches Tutorverhalten?
Mit KI können wir sehr unterschiedliche Lernansätze verfolgen.









Prüfend

Prüft Kenntnisse schrittweise, gibt Tipps, reagiert bewertend


Lösend

Liefert fertige Lösung und Lösungsweg in einer Antwort


Erklärend

Liefert strukturierte Lösung in Schritten, checkt Verständnis


Sokratisch

Steuert Lernweg durch suggestive Fragen in Richtung eines vordefinierten Ablaufs


Epistemisch

Gibt Feedback, Tipps, Strukturhilfen, lässt den Lösungsweg offen




KI sollte alle diese Lehrverhalten unterstützen können, aber vor allem einen Weg Richtung epistemische Tutoring bereiten, um so nachhaltig lebensnahe, höheres Denken Kompetenzen aufzubauen.

title: Designing Reliable AI Tutors for Secondary Education
text:
Which Tutor Behavior?
With AI, we can pursue very different learning approaches.









Assessing

Checks knowledge step by step, gives hints, responds evaluatively


Solving

Provides the complete solution and solution path in a single answer


Explaining

Delivers a structured solution in steps, checks understanding


Socratic

Guides the learning path through leading questions toward a predefined sequence


Epistemic

Gives feedback, hints, and structural support while leaving the solution path open




AI should be able to support all of these teaching behaviors, but above all should pave the way toward epistemic tutoring, in order to sustainably develop real-world, higher-order thinking competencies.

title: Designing Reliable AI Tutors for Secondary Education
text:
Epistemic AI Tutoring


Epistemic AI tutoring is inspired by “Common Standards for Rigor and Relevance in Teaching Academic Subjects” by Fred M. Newmann, M. Bruce King, and Dana L. Carmichael.
The authors propose that “authentic instruction” includes tasks that:

require the construction of knowledge (not merely recall),
require investigation, analysis, synthesis, and/or evaluation — higher-order thinking, and
have value beyond school (meaningful for learners’ lives or for the world).

This is highly desirable, but often falls short in everyday school practice.
Here, AI can play a supportive role.

Modular SW design allows for flexible implementation of different teaching behaviors and real-time monitoring of dialogue quality.



The system architecture is designed to allow for different teaching behaviors (assessing, solving, explaining, Socratic, epistemic) to be implemented and switched between.
Real-time monitoring of dialogue quality allows for immediate detection and correction of issues such as role drift, misinformation, or misalignment with learning goals.

Epistemic

text:
Didactic Quality 1/2
To illustrate the importance of monitoring and quality control, we repeated a AI-Tutor, AI-Student dialogue 10 times with the same initial conditions and prompts.


Despite of identical initial conditions, the dialogue diverges over time. We see deviations from the intended epistemic tutoring behavior, wrong pre-suppositions already in the first turn.
“An oral exam is not about helping the student to gain understanding, but about checking whether the student has already gained understanding.”

title: Designing Reliable AI Tutors for Secondary Education
text:
Didactic Quality 2/2
By the end of the didactic dialogue, the chatbot’s responses diverge significantly.


Warning (4%):  Tutor works on wrong pre-supposition: Act as advisor (wrong) not examiner.
Violation (3%):  Tutor incorrectly evaluates answers or discloses the solution.
50% of the dialogs show disturbed instructional role fidelity.

Here, AI can play a supportive role.

To concretize our AI tutoring concept, the learning approach is based on “Common Standards for Rigor and Relevance in Teaching Academic Subjects” by Fred M. Newmann, M. Bruce King, and Dana L. Carmichael, and by John Bransford’s work on learning for understanding and transfer.
Together, they argue that“authentic intellectual work” needs tasks that:

require the construction of knowledge (not merely recall),
require investigation, analysis, synthesis, and/or evaluation — higher-order thinking, and
support transfer beyond school, preparing learners for future learning and real-world use.

text:
Observations


Interaction patterns vary considerably:

targeted follow-up questions
step-by-step guidance
attempts to obtain complete solutions directly from the AI

Key insights:

AI systems must support learners flexibly and adapt to different learning strategies
The goal is not to replace students’ work, but to actively engage them in the learning process
If learners insist on excessive support, the tutor risks abandoning its pedagogical role

Epistemic AI-tutoring is a viable design approach

Embedding AI in authentic contexts is crucial

Design matters more than model capability alone

Explore scalability and long-term impact in larger studies

title: Designing Reliable AI Tutors for Secondary Education
text:
First Observations


Interaction patterns vary considerably:
Students use the AI tutor in very different ways, including: - try to find path on their own, using the tutor only for feedback and hints - accept step-by-step guidance, demanding a more structured solution path from the tutor, which led to conflicts - attempts to obtain complete solutions directly from the AI, which could lead to a loss of the tutor’s pedagogical role
Key insights:

AI session can lead to significant learning gains
AI systems must support learners flexibly and adapt to different learning strategies
We could see tutor taking a pedagogical role, but the quality of interaction needs to be hardened against students’ attempts to obtain complete solutions directly from the AI
If learners insist on excessive support, the tutor risks abandoning its pedagogical role
